p.s: The text extract from Act II, scene 2 by William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet is about them talking and reflecting about their love for each other.
The meaning of language has an important aspects concerning their relationship.
Romeo and Juliet both know that their love is against their familiesfamilies' willwills.
When Juliet realizes that Romeo is in the Capulet's orchard she immediately begins to worry about his life.
She is scarredscared that her relatives could find Romeo and is convinced of them killing Romeo in that case.
Romeo otherwise, seems blended by the love, so that he does not care what happens to him, as long as Juliet loves him.
Juliet is flattered by these words and expresses her feelings for Romeo in a monologue.
After that, both of them seem to have enough coragecourage and strength to fight together for their love.
The language also shows this development of the stability of their relationship.

At the very beginning in line 58f when Juliet thinks she is alone and talking to herself, she makes use of a personification: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound.
She is talking about Romeo.

They just have seen one time before this scene and Juliet means by this choice of words that even they have spoken that little and hears have not even heard a hundred words of him because there was no time to talk yet, she can still imagine the sound of his voice and the words he spoke.
The effect of using this stylistic / poetic device is that her words concerning Romeo are becoming more real.
They are literally coming to life.
Even if it's only a memory of Romeo's presence, with the personification it becomes easier for the reader to be able to have this reference.
In line 78 Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love the author, William Shakespeare, is making use of an oxymoron.

At this point of the scene Romeo , who hides in the dark to be with Juliet, is talking about how he does not care about being killed by Juliet's relatives, the Capulets, if that means Juliet would love him.
By that he means that he is willing to take the risk just for the love, which is very romantic.
The constellation of the word death and love in one sentence and line gives a dramatic effect, which is typical for the oxymoron.
It also has the effect that the contrast of these especially in the meaning two completely opposite words are drawing attention to the reader.
Further in the text extract where Juliet's gives her monologue takes place there is a repetition in line 88: Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny....
By that Juliet means that she would be glad to conform to social norms, but there is just no way to do that because she is in love with Romeo.
So the convention of such should be abolished.

To focus on the language there is to say that Juliet employ with the repetition of the word fain, which appeals to have the meaning gladly, that even she thinks the social norms have usch an impact on everything, she still is willing to love Romeo.
With the repetition she can point out how much she wants him and the whole statement is given more strength.
To conclude one can say that the poetic / stilisticstylistic devices, chosen by William Shakespeare, definitely have their sense of underlining the meaning of the validity.
The thesis, that the language is sufficient for showing the development of the love of Romeo and Juliet, is therefore to confirm.
In addition the loverslovers' reflection on their love agains the odds also changed.
They both now are willing to fight for their love.
